profile_positions.description:
JOT MARE and Europol's Information Clearing House (ICH) have been established as part of the EMSC. This type of fusion centre cooperation platform aims to improve Europol’s intelligence picture on migrant smuggling and to consolidate its support to partner law enforcement agencies, with a focus beyond EU borders on source and transit countries as well as on sea facilitated primary and secondary movements.

The ICH in particular makes effective use of assets and structures already in place, such as existing cooperation with Frontex and INTERPOL as a bridge to third countries. The ICH aims to initiate or further develop cooperation with less-traditional partners not immediately connected to the law enforcement environment – for example, military forces deployed as part of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions and operations, such as European Union Naval Force Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR Med) and the European Gendarmerie Force (EUROGENDFOR). Enhanced cooperation and improved information and intelligence sharing will contribute to detecting and selecting High Value Targets (HVT) more easily and setting up of Operational Task Forces (OTF).

JOT MARE and the establishment of the ICH are Europol/EMSC-led operational action embedded in the Operational Action Plan (OAP) 2018 on Facilitated Illegal Immigration (approved in COSI on 1 December 2017) as part of the EU Policy Cycle 2018-2021.

profile_positions.description:
Responsibilities:

-To establish and maintain an efficient police cooperation platform between the Romanian and the Irish National Police.
- To facilitate a fluent channel of communication with partner authorities in solving common problems in the law enforcement area with an emphasis on countering trans-border organized crime, in particular, human trafficking and migrant smuggling. 
- To provide specialist support and assistance to the Irish judicial authorities in relation to high profile criminal investigations into serious organized crime groups and to initiate and support bilateral investigations by Romanian and Irish Police.
- To research and identify the national/regional/international legal frameworks applicable in criminal matters, facilitate trans-national prosecutions related to organized crime cases and closely follow the process of International Requests for Assistance in criminal matters of joint interests.
- To participate as an observer in joint counter - organized crime operations and insure adequate support of the operational teams by providing relevant and up-to-date intelligence packages in relation to suspects, witnesses and/or victims of crime.
- To provide specialist support in relation to Romanian nationals, victims of crime in Ireland and facilitate, in conjunction with the relevant stakeholders, national and non-governmental organizations their safe and timely repatriation to Romania.
- To prepare and disseminate research documents and analytic reports on matters related to the Justice and Policing area for use by the MoIA HQ and/or the Head of Mission. 
- Act as Ambassador's councilor on Justice & Home Affairs matters and actively participate in the negotiation of bilateral judicial cooperation instruments.
- Cooperate and liaise with partners from government, non-government organizations, international actors, authorities of neighboring Member States (UK,France) as well as the private sector on Justice and Policing matters.

profile_positions.description:
Responsibilities:

As THB investigations officer I played an active role in two capacity building projects –“Reflex Romania” and “Strengthening law enforcement capacities for fighting THB in S-E Europe“.

During Project "Reflex Romania”- a joint British-Romanian initiative on countering organized immigration crime, I was directly involved in investigating organized crime groups suspected of THB and migrant smuggling. I often liaised and coordinated efforts with partner law enforcement – including Spain, France, The Netherland’s and The Czech Republic - government agencies, NGO's active in the field. I actively supported the Prosecutor’s Office by interviewing witnesses and victims of THB; I, additionally, oversaw the criminal investigation recommended the employment of special investigation methods for obtaining quality intelligence material. The supervisory role involved the coordination and support of the Project's 15 regional offices, overseeing the ongoing operations, case management and providing logistical support for investigations. I regularly prepared comprehensive briefings regarding the objectives, state of play and achievements, logistical requirements, recommended and performed acquisitions and distribution of equipment. 

As part of Project“Strengthening law enforcement capacities for fighting THB in S-E Europe“, a ICMPD & UNDP project aimed at implementing a Best Practices Manual for investigating THB, I was nominated National Training Coordinator. My duties involved liaising with all stakeholders, the setting up of training sessions for prosecutors, investigators and police cadets, planning, overseeing and coordinating seminars with a view to debate and analyze the value of the manual as a uniform training tool. Project reporting tasks required to regularly update the senior management on goals, activities and objectives. As part of this project I have also participated in a dedicated “train the trainers” course based on the new manual.
